sen.j: 引眉（ひきまゆ）とは、奈良時代から江戸時代にかけておこなわれた化粧法で、眉を剃る、または抜くことを意味する。
sen.e: Hikimayu is a makeup technique applied from the Nara period to Edo period, meaning to shave or pull out eyebrows.
Hikimayu is a makeup technique applied from the Nara period to the Edo period, meaning to shave or pull out eyebrows.
Hikimayu is a makeup technique applied from the Nara period to the Edo period, meaning to shave or pull out eyebrows.

sen.j: 眉を剃る、または抜いたあと、細い弓形の眉を墨で描く。
sen.e: After shaving or pulling out eyebrows, thin arc-shaped eyebrows were drawn with ink.
After shaving or pulling out eyebrows, thin arc-shaped eyebrows were drawn with ink.
After shaving or pulling out eyebrows, thin arc-shaped eyebrows were drawn with ink.

tit.j: 平安時代－安土桃山時代
tit.cmt: period 小文字にしました。

sen.j: 眉を剃る、または抜いたあと、除去した眉よりも高い位置に「殿上眉」という長円形の眉を墨で描く。
sen.e: After shaving or pulling out eyebrows, oval-shaped 'tenjo-mayu' eyebrows were drawn with ink at positions higher than the removed eyebrows.
After shaving or pulling out eyebrows, oval-shaped 'tenjo-mayu' eyebrows were drawn with ink at positions higher than the removed eyebrows.
After shaving or pulling out eyebrows, oval-shaped 'tenjo-mayu' eyebrows were drawn with ink at positions higher than the removed eyebrows.

sen.j: 元来は裳着の際に、お歯黒とセットで行われた。
sen.e: Originally, hikimayu was applied together with ohaguro (black painted teeth) at Mogi (coming-of-age ceremony for girls).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Originally, hikimayu was applied together with ohaguro (black painted teeth) at Mogi (coming-of-age ceremony for girls).
Originally, hikimayu was applied together with ohaguro (black painted teeth) at Mogi (coming-of-age ceremony for girls).

sen.j: 平安時代中期頃から男性貴族、平家の武将等の元服の時にも行うようになった。
sen.e: From around the mid Heian period and on, it was adopted into the genpuku (celebrate one's coming of age) ceremonies for male nobles and generals of the Taira family.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: From around the mid Heian period, it was adopted into the coming of age ceremonies for male nobles and generals of the Taira family.
From around the mid Heian period, it was adopted into the genpuku (coming-of-age) ceremonies for male nobles and generals of the Taira family.
sen.cmt: 元服 を追加しました。

sen.j: 室町時代以降は殿上眉の位置はさらに高くなり、能面にも写されるようになった。
sen.e: From the Muromachi period and on, the position of the tenjo-mayu became still higher, and the eyebrow style came to be incorporated into Noh masks.
From the Muromachi period on, the position of the tenjo-mayu became still higher, and the eyebrow style came to be incorporated into Noh masks.
From the Muromachi period on, the position of the tenjo-mayu became still higher, and the eyebrow style came to be incorporated into Noh masks.

sen.j: 江戸時代では以下に該当する女性のみの習慣となり、元服の際にお歯黒とセットで行われたものである。
sen.e: From the Edo period and on, hikimayu came to be limited to the women who meet the conditions below, and applied together with ohaguro at genpuku ceremonies.
From the Edo period on, hikimayu came to be limited to women who meet the conditions below, and was applied together with ohaguro at genpuku ceremonies.
From the Edo period on, hikimayu came to be limited to women who meet the conditions below, and was applied together with ohaguro at genpuku ceremonies.

sen.j: 既婚女性全般(お歯黒を付け、引眉する、但し武家（武士）の妻は出産後に引眉する)
sen.e: Married women in general (apply both ohaguro and hikimayu, except for women married to samurai families who were to apply hikimayu after giving birth to a child).
Married women in general (apply both ohaguro and hikimayu, except for women married to samurai families who were to apply hikimayu after giving birth to a child).
Married women in general (apply both ohaguro and hikimayu, except for women married to samurai families who were to apply hikimayu after giving birth to a child).

sen.j: 18～20歳以上の未婚女性(お歯黒を付けても引眉する場合としない場合有り)
sen.e: Unmarried women from age 18 to age 20 (even when applying ohaguro, hikimayu was optional).
Unmarried women from age 18 to age 20 (even when applying ohaguro, hikimayu was optional).
Unmarried women from age 18 to age 20 (even when applying ohaguro, hikimayu was optional).

sen.j: 江戸中期までは眉を剃る、または抜いたあと、元々の眉を薄い墨でなぞる。
sen.e: Until the mid Edo period, the original shapes of the eyebrows were drawn with dilute ink after they were shaved or pulled out
Until the mid Edo period, the original shapes of the eyebrows were drawn with dilute ink after they were shaved or pulled out
Until the mid Edo period, the original shapes of the eyebrows were drawn with dilute ink after they were shaved or pulled out.
sen.cmt: ピリオドを追加しました。

sen.j: 江戸後期以降は眉を剃る、または抜いたあと眉を描かない場合が多い。
sen.e: From the late Edo period and on, eyebrows were left undrawn after they were shaved or pulled out.
From the late Edo period and on, eyebrows were left undrawn after they were shaved or pulled out.
From the late Edo period and on, eyebrows were left undrawn after they were shaved or pulled out.

sen.j: なお、演劇や浮世絵などでは剃った跡を薄い青で表現する場合が多い、これを青黛と呼んでいる。
sen.e: In theatrical performances and ukiyoe (Japanese woodblock prints), eyebrows were drawn in pale blue after they were shaved or pulled out, which is a technique called seitai (drawing eyebrows with a blue pigment).
In theatrical performances and ukiyoe (Japanese woodblock prints), eyebrows were drawn in pale blue after they were shaved or pulled out, which is a technique called seitai.
In theatrical performances and ukiyoe (Japanese woodblock prints), eyebrows were drawn in pale blue after they were shaved or pulled out, which is a technique called seitai.

sen.j: なお、お歯黒を付けても眉を剃らない場合もあり、この場合は元服と呼ばれる。
sen.e: Wearing ohaguro without shaving eyebrows is referred to as genpuku.
sen.cmt: B21セルの内容と矛盾するようです。また、以下のデジタル大辞泉でも元服を「結婚した女性が歯を黒く染め、丸まげを結い、眉をそったこと」としています。http://kotobank.jp/word/%E5%85%83%E6%9C%8D
sen.e: Wearing ohaguro without shaving eyebrows is referred to as genpuku.
Wearing ohaguro without shaving eyebrows is referred to as genpuku.

sen.j: この他、幕末から明治時代にかけての写真や浮世絵に、2歳から12歳くらいの少女が、眉を剃ってるものをよく見かける。
sen.e: Other examples of shaving eyebrows are often seen in pictures and ukiyoe prints depicting girls from around age 2 to age 12 produced from the end of the Edo period to the Meiji period.
Other examples of shaving eyebrows are often seen in pictures and ukiyoe prints depicting girls from around age 2 to 12 produced from the end of the Edo period to the Meiji period.
Other examples of shaving eyebrows are often seen in pictures and ukiyoe prints depicting girls from around age 2 to 12 produced from the end of the Edo period to the Meiji period.

sen.j: 文明開化以降はお歯黒とともに衰退し、明治時代中期にはほとんどみられなくなった。
sen.e: After the civilization and enlightenment, both hikimayu and ohaguro declined and almost died out by the mid Meiji period.
After the civilization and enlightenment, both hikimayu and ohaguro declined and almost died out by the mid Meiji period.
After the civilization and enlightenment, both hikimayu and ohaguro declined and almost died out by the mid Meiji period.

sen.j: 現代では一部の演劇、また伝統的な祭りの際にみられるだけである。
sen.e: At present, it is applied only in some theatrical performances and traditional festivals.
At present, it is applied only in some theatrical performances and traditional festivals.
At present, it is applied only in some theatrical performances and traditional festivals.
